dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, big tech news this week, uh, the Supreme Court has weighed in on Apple's App Store.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, big tech news this week, uh, the Supreme Court has weighed in on Apple's App Store.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Supreme Court Monday cleared the way for the antitrust suit that centers on Apples walled garden approach to the App store, which has drawn criticism from some companies that use it to deliver services to iPhone users.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, the whole "walled garden" thing, right? I heard something about it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, the whole walled garden thing, right? I heard something about it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. They basically cleared the way for Apple's defense in a major suit. Meaning, this case, you know, about their app store policies, it's not going to continue through the courts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. They basically cleared the way for Apple's defense in a major suit. Meaning, this case, you know, about their app store policies, it's not going to continue through the courts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Supreme Court Monday cleared the way for the antitrust suit... The case will continue through the courts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, so a win for Apple then? I mean, what was the core issue here? The, uh, the commission, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, so a win for Apple then? I mean, what was the core issue here? The, uh, the commission, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That fee also is at the heart of the dispute that rose to the Supreme Court.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that was definitely at the heart of it. A group of iPhone owners sued back in 2011, arguing Apple essentially monopolizes the app market and, ironically, that their fees actually lead to *lower* prices for consumers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that was definitely at the heart of it. A group of iPhone owners sued back in twenty eleven, arguing Apple essentially monopolizes the app market and, ironically, that their fees actually lead to lower prices for consumers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Four iPhone owners filed a suit in 2011, claiming that Apple monopolizes the app aftermarketand extracts a fee that results in higher prices for millions of consumers who use their phones to buy food, arrange transportation or buy movie tickets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Lower prices? That's... I mean, that's not what you usually hear. But that 30% cut, or 15% for long-term subs, that's what everyone talks about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Lower prices? That's... I mean, that's not what you usually hear. But that thirty percent cut, or fifteen percent for long-term subs, that's what everyone talks about.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spotify and Netflix have taken issue with the 30% commission that Apple collects from an apps first-year subscriptions and a 15% share of revenue generated from long-term subscribers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And this article actually says, get this, Spotify and Netflix have, like, "lauded" Apple's "benevolent" commission. Which, frankly, given what we know about Spotify's CEO often complaining, feels a little, um, contradictory to me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And this article actually says, get this, Spotify and Netflix have, like, lauded Apple's benevolent commission. Which, frankly, given what we know about Spotify's C E O often complaining, feels a little, um, contradictory to me.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spotify and Netflix have taken issue with the 30% commission that Apple collects from an apps first-year subscriptions and a 15% share of revenue generated from long-term subscribers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Yeah, I was just gonna say! I thought Spotify was always pretty vocal about how unfair it was.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I was just gonna say! I thought Spotify was always pretty vocal about how unfair it was.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That follows an earlier move by Spotify, which filed a complaint in March with the European Commission alleging unfair business practices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, apparently, it's what the article claims. But the Supreme Court, Justice Kavanaugh writing for the majority, basically embraced Apple's argument that they're just drawing a clear line between retailers and suppliers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, apparently, it's what the article claims. But the Supreme Court, Justice Kavanaugh writing for the majority, basically embraced Apple's argument that they're just drawing a clear line between retailers and suppliers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Justice Brett Kavanaugh, writing for the courts 5-4 majority, rejected Apples arguments, writing that the technology giant sought to draw an arbitrary and unprincipled line among retailers, based upon their arrangements with suppliers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So it's not just about Apple. This could have huge implications for, like, Google's Play Store, Amazon's digital services, all these platform owners, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's not just about Apple. This could have huge implications for, like, Google's Play Store, Amazon's digital services, all these platform owners, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That decision could have implications for Google or Amazon. For anyone who runs an app store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Consumer advocates are saying it's a big deal. It sets a precedent for how these digital retailers operate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Consumer advocates are saying it's a big deal. It sets a precedent for how these digital retailers operate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It could mean theres going to be a variety of new things the platforms have to consider, says John Bergmayer, an attorney for the consumer advocacy group Public Citizen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And despite all this, Apple itself says most apps are free anyway, and they get nothing from those. It's only if developers sell digital services through the App Store that they take a cut.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And despite all this, Apple itself says most apps are free anyway, and they get nothing from those. It's only if developers sell digital services through the App Store that they take a cut.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The vast majority of apps on the App Store are free and Apple gets nothing from them, Apple said in a statement. The only instance where Apple shares in revenue is if the developer chooses to sell digital services through the App Store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they say developers set their own prices. But it's still, you know, the "player and referee" argument that Spotify's CEO, Daniel Ek, has often made. Like, they control the store *and* they compete with apps in it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they say developers set their own prices. But it's still, you know, the player and referee argument that Spotify's C E O, Daniel Ek, has often made. Like, they control the store and they compete with apps in it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Developers set the price they want to charge for their app and Apple has no role in that... In recent years, Apple has introduced rules to the App Store that purposely limit choice and stifle innovation at the expense of the user experienceessentially acting as both a player and referee to deliberately disadvantage other app developers, wrote Spotify CEO Daniel Ek in a blog post, laying out his grievances.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's a tricky balance, for sure. Makes you wonder what comes next for app developers trying to, uh, navigate that landscape.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a tricky balance, for sure. Makes you wonder what comes next for app developers trying to, uh, navigate that landscape.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. A lot of money flows through there, even if it's not Apple's biggest revenue stream, it's massive for developers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. A lot of money flows through there, even if it's not Apple's biggest revenue stream, it's massive for developers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apples app store has been a significant source of revenue for developers, who received about $120 billion over the last 11 years.
